author: Krishnadas Rajagopal
text:
Centre’s letter to States reveals lack of concerted efforts to provide essential services

Eleven years after the National Disaster Management Act (NDMA) became law in 2005, havoc and humanitarian crisis caused by natural disasters like the recent Chennai floods have opened the eyes of the Centre that much is to be done in States across the country to ensure that disaster victims access even minimum standards of relief.

A letter written by the Joint Secretary, Policy and Plan, National Disaster Management Authority, on February 25 to the Chief Secretaries of all States has called for immediate action to frame a road map to provide ‘Minimum Standards of Relief’ mandated under Section 12 of the NDMA in disaster-hit areas.

The letter, on record before the Supreme Court, reveals there has been a lack of concerted effort by the States to comply with Section 12 to provide essential services such as shelter, food, drinking water, medical cover and sanitation at relief camps for disaster victims. A Bench led by Justice Dipak Misra on Friday ordered the Chief Secretaries to complete the framing of guidelines while remarking that providing minimum standards of relief under the NDMA is a fundamental duty of the State.
title: Ensure minimum standards of relief to disaster victims: Supreme Court
